bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 9, 1875

div1.p: Reed reiterates his devotion to her. He describes a view of the planets by telescope.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 9, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willets Point,
New York Harbor,
Septr 9th 75.

div1.p:
From
early morning, I have been
much perplexed with think-
ing. Can you imagine the cause
of my perplexity? I'll tell
you. It is simply that I
don't know with what I
shall supply these pages
in order to make them in-
teresting. I haven't been
to the City, since I last wrote;
nor have I taken part
in any serenades or sailing
excursions, or been to see
any ladies, (I've had several op-
portunities, but didn't improve
them,) and hence these fruit-
ful topics of discourse are
wanting & their loss is much
felt. To tell the truth, I have been
very lazy, during the past week-
I have read but little and have
not so much as looked into
my French Grammar, nor do
I intend to do so, until I
get another and better one.
It is disagreeable enough to
have to study French without
any drawbacks, and to pursue
the study, under disadvan-
tages, is simply intolerable.
Excuse my forcible expressions.
Having neither serenades nor
excursions to write about,
what shall I say? If I were
by your side, I would not be
at a loss, as I could ea-
sily say a thousand and one
foolish things (this you will
endorse, I'm sure) but then
same expressions, committed
to paper, would appear very
insipid. I could fill several
pages with telling the same
old story, but I'm afraid
you would grow weary with
listening. “Surely,” you would
exclaim, “a woman doesn't
care to forever hear that
she is loved -- the song,
too often sung, loses its
enchantment.” Now whether
this is true or not, I am
not quite sure, although
I am inclined to think that it
is true, to a certain extent, and
in certain cases. In others, I am
confident that it is not the
case. For instance, I don't be-
lieve that the charming Mur-
freesboro widow whom I saw
at a distance, & to whom you
would not introduce me,
(your object I never could pene-
trate,) would every grow tired
of hearing the ancient & much
counted Dr L.'s plaintive mur-
murings! On the contrary, I be-
lieve, that they would be “as
welcome as the cry, that
told the Indian Isles were
nigh, to the world-seeking
Genoese; when the land-winds,
from woods of palms, and orange
groves & fields of balm,
blew o'er the Haytien seas-”
Before it escapes my memory,
permit me to ask, how do does the
venerable Dr (I wouldn't dare
thus to allude to him did not
many miles intervene, & then
he is so young,) progress in
the estimation of the fascina-
ting widow? Does she deign to
smile upon him, or is it
likely that he will take
cold “while shivering in the
shade of beauty's frown”?
Does the gay & sportive
Mr Williams often cross
his orb? Or has he aban-
doned the field as lost? What
friendly feelings must ex-
ist between them! May the
bravest win, and long may
he live to bask in the sun-
light of her smiles! May the
words of the Poet, “that man I
say who hath a tongue I say
is no man, if with that tongue
he cannot win a woman,
serve to uphold the drooping
spirits of him who meets
defeat! Thus do I leave them
in Fortune's care.

On Tuesday night, last, I was
entertained with a view of
the Heavens, through the kind-
ness of Lieut. Rossell. Of course
I mean an telescopic view-
We took a peep at Mars --
saw the beautiful rings
of Saturn -- & watched the
movements of Luna as
she pursued her trackless
path through the immensity
of space. I was most anx-
ious to look at Jupiter,
but unfortunately, it was
too late at night to see him.
I felt sure that in looking at
him, tha I should have the
exquisite pleasure of seeing
the reflection of your darling
face! and this would more
than repay my evening's toil.
Mind, or I will yet see you.
Would that I was in Mur-
freesboro, these charmings
evenings-! I have never seen
nights more beautiful-
Early in the evening I take
my chair out to the veranda
& so charmed am I with the
silent beauty of the scene
without, that I often find
myself unconsciously watching
the Heavens till a late
hour. What an hour it
is for reflection! And Oh!
how my heart swells with
gratitude, when I think how
fortunate my lot has been!
Had I met with disappoint-
ment and defeat at every turn
in my life, still to have won
your love, my darling E., is
all that I can ask! For thou
art my own, sweet Emilie,-
“with that name life's dearest
hopes and memories Come”!
I trust that e're another moon
shall wax & wane, that weI
may be permitted to gaze
upon the beauties of nature
in your society. At least, this
is my expectation- I am afraid
that if I postpone my visit
till later, that I will be ordered
away & be deprived of all
chance of coming. But of this,
more at another time.
div1.closer:
Believe
me, my darling, your fond & devoted Walter. Excuse mistakes.
